p: On the other hand, metapopulation models describe the epidemic dynamics of subpopulations in spatially separated patches connected via migration pathways and deal with human mobility patterns at a macroscopic level [ 12, 13]. The statistical properties of various human traveling patterns via transportation networks, such as airlines, railways, and commuting roads, have been well incorporated into the metapopulation models [ 14â€“ 25]. Compared with individual-based models, the metapopulation models are analytically tractable. The previous studies have theoretically derived the global invasion threshold [ 18, 20, 21] and the critical intervention threshold for containment of epidemics [ 26] in metapopulation models with heterogeneous patch connectivity. However, the stochastic nature of the movement of individual hosts is not explicitly considered in the metapopulation models because they only describe the mobility dynamics of subpopulations.
